issues.title: Time4J - civil twilight times not available for some locations in Alaska
issues.body:
Time4J base library version :  5.2. Also, observed the same issue in Time4J base 5.6.
Java version : 12.

**Description**

```
SolarTime solarTime = SolarTime.ofLocation(64.90127423829784, -147.87481800058953);
LocalDate localDate = LocalDate.of(2020, 6, 18);
PlainDate plainDate = TemporalType.LOCAL_DATE.translate(locationDate);
plainDate.get(solarTime.sunrise(Twilight.CIVIL)); // this is returning Optional.empty()
```
The library is returning Optional.empty() for the above location and date. Also, observed that the library is returning Optional.empty() for all dates between 16th May 2020 and 26th July 2020.

**Expected behaviour**
The library should provide civil twilight times for the above mentioned location and dates. https://www.timeanddate.com/sun/usa/fairbanks?month=6&year=2020 mentions that civil twilight is b/n 00:46 and 02:58 for 18th June.

**Actual behaviour**
The library is returning Optional.empty()

**Additional Questions**

 I've checked the SolarTime documentation, http://www.time4j.net/javadoc-en/net/time4j/calendar/astro/SolarTime.html#sunrise-net.time4j.calendar.astro.Twilight- and http://www.time4j.net/javadoc-en/net/time4j/calendar/astro/SolarTime.html#sunset-net.time4j.calendar.astro.Twilight- , there's no description of how to interpret the output returned on executing the ChronoFunction returned by sunrise and sunset APIs when the output is Optional.empty(). 

Does it mean the civil twilight data is not available? or Does it mean there is no civil twilight at that location and date? Can I please get an explanation of how to interpret the output when it is Optional.empty()

issues.title: EastAsianCalendar cannot operate on time units smaller than a day.
issues.body:
I was trying to use the plus method on ChineseCalendar to add a number of seconds, and there does not seem to be any way. At least not in 4.99-beta.
ChineseCalendar.Unit  ChineseCalendar.Unit has no unit smaller than DAYS. None of the arithmetic methods will accept any argument types except ChineseCalendar.Unit, and there is no way to convert other units into  ChineseCalendar.Unit. This effectually blocks any operations with ClockUnit on units of time smaller than an day.
I'm hacking around on the source to see what happens when I insert hours-minutes-seconds into the ChineseCalendar.Unit enum, but it is unclear why there are different incompatible types for:

net.time4j.CalendarUnit
net.time4j.ClockUnit
net.time4j.calendar.ChineseCalendar.Unit

and no ChineseCalendar ClockUnit at all.

I was trying to use the GapResolver, and have even resorted to copy/pasting a solution you yourself posted on StackOverflow. However, it keeps throwing the error below:
`java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: net.time4j.tz.TransitionResolver: [gap=NEXT_VALID_TIME,overlap=EARLIER_OFFSET]
at net.time4j.tz.PlatformTimezone.with(PlatformTimezone.java:446)
at com.test.Main.main(Main.java:275)`

From looking at that section of code, I don't see why that's happening. You're switching the enum value, and the enum I'm using is one of the ones defined in the switch, yet it's hitting the default outcome.

issues.body:
"IST" is ambivalent and can point to different timezones like "Asia/Kolkata" (most probable) or "Asia/Jerusalem" or "Asia/Colombo" or even "Europe/Dublin". If someone is located in India (iso-3166-country-code "IN") such a person would expect "Asia/Kolkata" etc. So we can implement a similar strategy like in case of US.

Of course, if someone does not specify the country at all or use another country, then parsing will fail without explicitly setting the preferred timezone. This standard behaviour must not be changed to prevent the user getting wrong results without exceptions - see also 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34768351/how-to-solve-invalid-date-format-error-in-scala.

Note: This small enhancement is only relevant for standard smart style, not for strict style where ambivalent tz names will always be rejected if a preferred timezone was not set.
issues.title: Improve parsing of short tz name "IST" in smart style

issues.title: SolarTime examples are not up to date
issues.body:
Examples in the documentation of `SolarTime` class are not valid anymore (in both of _Time4J_ and _Time4A_). 

Current documentation:
```java
PlainDate date = PlainDate.of(2017, 12, 22);
TZID tzid = () -> "Africa/Dar_es_Salaam"; // Tanzania: UTC+03:00

// high altitude implies earlier sunrise and later sunset
SolarTime kibo5895 =
  SolarTime.ofLocation()
     .southernLatitude(3, 4, 0)
     .easternLongitude(37, 21, 33)
     .atAltitude(5895)
     .usingCalculator(StdSolarCalculator.TIME4J) // this calculator takes into account the altitude
     .build();

assertThat(
  date.get(kibo5895.sunrise(tzid)).get(),
  is(PlainTime.of(6, 10, 34)));
assertThat(
  date.get(kibo5895.sunset(tzid)).get(),
  is(PlainTime.of(18, 47, 48)));
```
I recommend to convert it to the following:
```java
PlainDate date = PlainDate.of(2017, 12, 22);
TZID tzid = () -> "Africa/Dar_es_Salaam"; // Tanzania: UTC+03:00

// high altitude implies earlier sunrise and later sunset
SolarTime kibo5895 =
  SolarTime.ofLocation()
     .southernLatitude(3, 4, 0)
     .easternLongitude(37, 21, 33)
     .atAltitude(5895)
     .inTimezone(tzid)
     .usingCalculator(StdSolarCalculator.TIME4J) // this calculator takes into account the altitude
     .build();

assertThat(
  date.get(kibo5895.sunrise()).get().toZonalTimestamp(tzid).toTime(),
  is(PlainTime.of(6, 10, 35)));
assertThat(
  date.get(kibo5895.sunset()).get().toZonalTimestamp(tzid).toTime(),
  is(PlainTime.of(18, 47, 47)));
```
Note that assertions should be converted to **T06:10:35** and **T18:47:47**!

issues.title: Incorrect sign in last term of calculation of mean lunar anomaly?
issues.body:
Hello,

Please correct me if I am wrong, but I understood from Meeus 2nd Ed. (1998) that the last term of this line (474 in file `MoonPhase.java`) should not be positive, but instead _negative_:

Currently it is this:

```
double meanAnomalyMoon =
134.9633964 + (477198.8675055 + (0.0087414 + ((1.0 / 69699) + (1.0 / 14712000) * jct) * jct) * jct) * jct;
```

I believe it should be corrected to this:
```
double meanAnomalyMoon =
134.9633964 + (477198.8675055 + (0.0087414 + ((1.0 / 69699) - (1.0 / 14712000) * jct) * jct) * jct) * jct;
```

issues.title: Approximated normalization of durations should be more clever
issues.body:
It is somehow for debate if this can be considered as bug due to the approximate nature of this kind of normalization, but ... following test fails:

```
assertThat(
            Duration.<IsoUnit>of(60 * 60 * 24 * 365, ClockUnit.SECONDS)
                        .with(Duration.approximateMaxUnitOnly()),
            is(Duration.of(1, YEARS)));
```

At least this edge case of a duration in seconds summing up to almost a year (or often equals to a year) should succeed. Internally, the algorith should choose the best appropriate maximum unit for a given amount in seconds.

issues.title: AstronomicalSeason fails for years like 999_999_999
issues.body:
For such years, even the double primitive has numerical overflow! The precision according to Meeus should normally be limited to years in the range -1000 until +3000. Taking into account a side note of Meeus on p.178, we can slightly extend this range to -2000 until +3000.

So the appropriate fix is to limit the supported range and to document it.

We have received an exception as below:
```
java.util.MissingResourceException:
```

issues.body:
Hi, according to documentation for using Time4A in android I added this line in app gradle:

`implementation group: 'net.time4j', name: 'time4j-android', version: '4.0-2018e'`

but I got this error while syncing gradle:

`Failed to resolve: net.time4j:time4j-android:4.0-2018e`

in mvnrepository.com website the latest version of Time4J Android is 3.44.4-2018e . so I change implementation to this and gradle built successfully:

`implementation group: 'net.time4j', name: 'time4j-android', version: '3.44.4-2018e'`

I just wanted to inform you for this issue

issues.title: SimpleInterval.Factory is wrong about open or closed interval boundaries
issues.body:
Two mistakes:

- The documentation of methods "between(...)" and "until(...") pretends half-open intervals as result but really this depends on if the underlying timeline is calendrical (=> closed intervals) or not
- The "parse(...)"-methods always produce half-open intervals but for calendrical timelines this behaviour should be change to producing closed intervals (as standard in the rest of Time4J)

issues.title: Invalid Hispanic display name
issues.body:
In the following snippet we try to display Hispanic name in English:
```
for (TextWidth textWidth : TextWidth.values()) {
    System.out.print(textWidth + ": ");
    System.out.println(HistoricEra.HISPANIC.getDisplayName(Locale.ENGLISH, textWidth));
}
```
Output:
```
WIDE: Era de César
ABBREVIATED: Era
SHORT: Era
NARROW: Era
```
As shown in the output, the display name in` WIDE` width is in different language than English. In addition, in other width formats the display name (`Era`) is generic and doesn't seem to have Hispanic meaning.

issues.title: stdResourceLoader issue on windows
issues.body:
Hi ,
i am using the library to calculate sunrise/sunset in a specific location ,i am running the library in a java ee environment on windows.
after getting an exception that Provider net.time4j.scale.spi.DefaultLeapSecondProviderSPI could not be instantiated , i have looked into the code and have analyzed the difference between running it in an se environment and in the environment above. seems like on stdResourceLoader locate method is taking protected domain and appending the resource relative location to it. the problem is that while uri must contains forward slash only , on windows environment getProtectedDomain may return backwards slash(double backward slash of-course).
i suggest before appending them and creating a uri - replace the backwards slashes with a forward one.

issues.title: Throwing IllegalArgumentException while formatting minimum date of Minguo calendar
issues.body:
After running the following code
```
CalendarSystem<MinguoCalendar> calsys = MinguoCalendar.axis().getCalendarSystem();
MinguoCalendar minDate = calsys.transform(calsys.getMinimumSinceUTC()); // BEFORE_ROC-1000001911-01-01
ChronoFormatter<MinguoCalendar> formatter = ChronoFormatter
        .ofPattern("yyyy", PatternType.CLDR, Locale.ENGLISH, MinguoCalendar.axis());
System.out.println(formatter.format(minDate));
```
we get
```
IllegalArgumentException: Element YEAR_OF_ERA cannot be printed as the formatted value 1000001911 exceeds the maximum width of 9.
```
while expecting `1000001911` as output (because `minDate` is formattable).

We suggest to change the minimum date of Minguo calendar to `BEFORE_ROC-999999999-01-01`

In other word, we suggest to override `getMinimumSinceUTC` method of `MinguoCalendar` class as
```
@Override
public long getMinimumSinceUTC() {
    return -365242521549; // BEFORE_ROC-999999999-01-01
}
```

issues.title: Replace ResourceBundle in module environment
issues.body:
**The Jigsaw specification prohibits the usage of class `ResourceBundle.Control` in named modules.**

But this class is essential for Time4J in order to realize specific search strategies and fallback strategies (and reading UTF-8-files). So a complete replacement of the whole `ResourceBundle`-stuff is urgently needed. Note: It is unfortunately not sufficient to simply remove the customized `Control`-class and use the default one because the data structure induced by CLDR-data requires special search strategies.

Unfortunately a backwards incompatible break, thanks to Oracle but it is a showstopper when Time4J is executed on the module path in Java-9 or later. See also the problems of other people:

- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44167502/how-to-configure-resourcebundle-no-fallback-control-in-java-9?noredirect=1&lq=1
- https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/yasson/issues/72
- https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8190696 (Oracle rejects any further action)

This concerns the classes `SolarTerm` and `EastAsianST` on the Android platform. The usage of this method should be simply removed.

The problem only occurs if the chinese language is in effect.

issues.title: Clarify that class SolarTime only expects LMT-dates not zoned dates
issues.body:
The subtile difference between an LMT-date (in local mean time - bound to a geographical longitude) and a zoned date (bound to a civil timezone) is usually invisible for determining solar time unless we also consider following rare edge cases:

- eastern part of Kiribati
- Samoa
- western part of Aleutes
- some islands eastern for New Zealand

Common feature of these areas is the fact that the offset induced by geographical longitude does not fit the timezone offset such that the date changes even at noon. Example for Samoa which changed the side along the international date border in 2011:

	SolarTime apia =
		SolarTime.ofLocation().southernLatitude(13, 50, 0).westernLongitude(171, 45, 0).build();
	System.out.println(PlainDate.of(2011, 12, 29).get(apia.sunshine(PACIFIC.APIA)));
	System.out.println(PlainDate.of(2011, 12, 30).get(apia.sunshine(PACIFIC.APIA)));
	System.out.println(PlainDate.of(2011, 12, 31).get(apia.sunshine(PACIFIC.APIA)));

Output:

> Sunshine[utc=2011-12-29T17:01:06Z/2011-12-30T05:57:05Z,local=2011-12-29T07:01:06/2011-12-29T19:57:05,length=46559]
> Sunshine[utc=2011-12-30T17:01:39Z/2011-12-31T05:57:29Z,local=2011-12-31T07:01:39/2011-12-31T19:57:29,length=46550]
> Sunshine[utc=2011-12-31T17:02:13Z/2012-01-01T05:57:52Z,local=2012-01-01T07:02:13/2012-01-01T19:57:52,length=46539]

Users sitting on Samoa island will find this behaviour strange if they are forced to input a date which is one day earlier than their official civil date (after 2011).

**Solution:**

- Enhance documentation of `SolarTime` by a new paragraph explaining the semantics of LMT-dates
- New method in class `SolarTime.Builder` with the signature: `public Builder inTimezone(TZID)` for switching the interpretation of all input dates as zoned dates in all lambda expressions

@forrestguice Your code in your suntime-app is not affected by this solution and is still okay since it fortunately uses LMT-dates.

Some people have reported app crashes when deserializing compiled tz data, although I have not yet been able to reproduce it. Anyway, a closer look at [current proguard rules](https://github.com/MenoData/Time4A/blob/master/time4j-android/consumer-proguard-rules.pro) makes sense for sake of robustness. 

About serialization and proguard see also: https://www.guardsquare.com/en/proguard/manual/examples#serializable

Another example is interesting for comparison and maybe reproducibility: https://github.com/reisub/ZonedDateTimeProguardBug

Actually, the algorithm for parsing zone names has difficulties if the zone name is immediately followed by any letters a-z or A-Z. Example for a failing unit-test:

        ChronoFormatter<Moment> f =
            ChronoFormatter.setUp(Moment.axis(), Locale.ENGLISH)
                .addPattern("MMM dd HH:mm:ss ", PatternType.CLDR)
                .addShortTimezoneName(Collections.<TZID>singleton(ASIA.KOLKATA))
                .addPattern("'X' yyyy", PatternType.CLDR)
                .build();
        assertThat(
            f.parse("Dec 31 07:30:00 ISTX 2016"),
            is(PlainTimestamp.of(2016, 12, 31, 2, 0).atUTC()));

issues.title: v4.30: Conversion of Time4J-Duration to temporal amount sometimes broken
issues.body:
Test case:

        Duration<CalendarUnit> d = Duration.parseCalendarPeriod("P8W");
        LocalDate ld = LocalDate.of(2017, 9, 17);
        System.out.println(PlainDate.from(ld).plus(d)); // 2017-11-12
        System.out.println(ld.plus(d.toTemporalAmount())); // exception

> 
> java.time.temporal.UnsupportedTemporalTypeException: Unsupported unit: Seconds
> 	at java.time.LocalDate.plus(LocalDate.java:1241)

issues.title: Dependency issue with version 4.27.1
issues.body:
Due to wrong dependency version of time4j-i18n in version 4.27.1, my maven project now won't compile. It stuck with error like this:

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project xxx: Could not resolve dependencies for project yyy: Failed to collect dependencies at zzz -> net.time4j:time4j-range:jar:4.13 -> net.time4j:time4j-i18n:jar:4.27.1 -> net.time4j:time4j-core:jar:[4.28,): No versions available for net.time4j:time4j-core:jar:[4.28,) within specified range -> [Help 1]
```

Even though version 4.27.2 already fixed the wrong dependency (4929151a9584f110e4b95e854a83012355b482af), maven still [iterates through all the matching dependency versions](https://eclipse.googlesource.com/aether/aether-core/+/master/aether-impl/src/main/java/org/eclipse/aether/internal/impl/DefaultDependencyCollector.java#402) and recursively check all the child dependencies. And because time4j-range v4.13 declares its dependency of time4j-i18n as:

```
<dependency>
    <groupId>net.time4j</groupId>
    <artifactId>time4j-core</artifactId>
    <version>[4.13,)</version>
    <scope>compile</scope>
</dependency>
```

it matches with 4.13, 4.14, 4.15, ..., 4.17, 4.17.1, and 4.17.2.

I tried to search if it's possible to exclude 4.17.1 when maven resolve the dependencies, but I couldn't find any solution. And I do not have any control over the project that includes time4j-i18n to upgrade its version. Anybody has workaround for this?

Additionally, can I suggest to use fixed version instead of a range of valid versions? It seems to be a good practice to ensure more consistent builds.

issues.title: Improve and fix parsing of decimal elements
issues.body:
The [LDAP-syntax](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4517#section-3.3.13) can unfortunately not yet been parsed due to some deficiencies in the format engine around decimal elements. Following code should success but actually fails:

```
        ChronoFormatter<PlainDate> df =
            ChronoFormatter.setUp(PlainDate.axis(), Locale.ROOT)
                .addFixedInteger(PlainDate.YEAR, 4)
                .addFixedInteger(PlainDate.MONTH_AS_NUMBER, 2)
                .addFixedInteger(PlainDate.DAY_OF_MONTH, 2)
                .build();
        ChronoFormatter<Moment> mf =
            ChronoFormatter.setUp(Moment.axis(), Locale.US) 
                .addCustomized(PlainDate.COMPONENT, df)
                .addFixedInteger(PlainTime.DIGITAL_HOUR_OF_DAY, 2)
                .startOptionalSection()
                .addFixedInteger(PlainTime.MINUTE_OF_HOUR, 2)
                .startOptionalSection()
                .addFixedInteger(PlainTime.SECOND_OF_MINUTE, 2)
                .startOptionalSection()
                .addLiteral('.', ',')
                .addFraction(PlainTime.NANO_OF_SECOND, 1, 9, false)
                .endSection()
                .endSection()
                .endSection()
                .addTimezoneOffset(DisplayMode.SHORT, false, Collections.singletonList("Z"))
                .or()
                .addCustomized(PlainDate.COMPONENT, df)
                .addFixedInteger(PlainTime.DIGITAL_HOUR_OF_DAY, 2)
                .addFixedDecimal(PlainTime.DECIMAL_MINUTE)
                .addTimezoneOffset(DisplayMode.SHORT, false, Collections.singletonList("Z"))
                .or()
                .addCustomized(PlainDate.COMPONENT, df)
                .addFixedDecimal(PlainTime.DECIMAL_HOUR)
                .addTimezoneOffset(DisplayMode.SHORT, false, Collections.singletonList("Z"))
                .build();
        assertThat(
            mf.parse("199412160532-0500").toString(),
            is("1994-12-16T10:32:00Z"));
        assertThat(
            mf.parse("199412160532Z").toString(),
            is("1994-12-16T05:32:00Z"));
        assertThat(
            mf.parse("20161231185960.123456789-0500").toString(),
            is("2016-12-31T23:59:60,123456789Z"));
        assertThat(
            mf.parse("201612311859.25-0500").toString(),
            is("2016-12-31T23:59:15Z"));
        assertThat(
            mf.parse("2016123118.25-0500").toString(),
            is("2016-12-31T23:15:00Z"));

```

issues.title: RFC-1123-formatter must support northamerican zones
issues.body:
The RFC-1123-spec says in section 5.2.14:

>          There is a strong trend towards the use of numeric timezone
>          indicators, and implementations SHOULD use numeric timezones
>          instead of timezone names.  However, all implementations MUST
>          accept either notation.  If timezone names are used, they MUST
>          be exactly as defined in RFC-822.

However, the expression `Moment.formatterRFC1123()` does not support the abbreviations EST, EDT, etc.

Note: Military zones like A-Y (without J) should still not be supported because the original RFC-822-spec had used wrong signs (which is also noted in RFC-1123 resulting in the statement that "military time zones in RFC-822 headers carry no information").

issues.title: Regression: Misleading error message
issues.body:
When printing instants or moments without timezone, the error message is misleading, i.e. speaks about too many digits etc. But the message should point the user to the real cause, namely missing timezone. Such a message had been active in earlier releases but was unfortunately lost during optimization work on the format engine. Example code:

```
        ChronoPrinter<Instant> printer =
            ChronoFormatter.ofPattern(
                "uuuu-MM-dd HH:mm:ssXXX",
                PatternType.CLDR,
                Locale.ROOT,
                Moment.axis(TemporalType.INSTANT)
            ); // here missing: .withTimezone(ZonalOffset.UTC)
        printer.format(Instant.now()); // throws exception with bad message

```

issues.title: Clarify documentation of AdjustableElement.atFloor() and .atCeiling()
issues.body:
The documentation should be better. Until now it only says:

> ElementOperator<T> atFloor()
> Rounds down an entity by setting all child elements to minimum. 
> Returns: operator directly applicable on local types without timezone

What it does not say is what happens if there are no child elements. In this case, the operator is just the identity operator (no-op). Example: `DAY_OF_WEEK.atFloor()` is a no-op if applied on `PlainDate`, but does something if applied on `PlainTimestamp` (because latter has a time component which would be set to zero in floor-example).

issues.title: Ambivalence parsing check sometimes faulty
issues.body:
If the elements `PlainDate.MONTH_OF_YEAR` and `PlainDate.MONTH_AS_NUMBER` are simultaneously used in format pattern and default values then the ambivalence check can go wrong. Example:

		ChronoFormatter<Moment> ff =
			ChronoFormatter.setUp(Moment.axis(), Locale.ROOT).addFixedInteger(PlainDate.YEAR, 4)
			.startOptionalSection().addFixedNumerical(PlainDate.MONTH_OF_YEAR, 2).addPattern(
				"[dd[HH[mm[ss]]]]]",
				PatternType.CLDR_24
			).build().withTimezone(ZonalOffset.UTC);
		ff =
			ff.withDefault(PlainDate.MONTH_AS_NUMBER, 4).withDefault(PlainDate.DAY_OF_MONTH, 1)
			.withDefault(PlainTime.ISO_HOUR, 0).with(Leniency.STRICT);
		System.out.println(ff.parse("201605041636"));

Observed behaviour:

> java.text.ParseException: Conflict found: Text {201605041636} with element MONTH_OF_YEAR {MAY}, but parsed entity has element value {APRIL}.

Solution: The parser should recognize that both elements have finally the same meaning (although different in value type).

issues.title: Years in far future should not require a positive sign
issues.body:
According to the original [CLDR-specification](http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/tr35-dates.html#dfst-year),
years like AD 12345 are not automatically supposed to have a positive sign in front of the year number. Time4J should only ensure this sign if applied in context of class `Iso8601Format` but not for general patterns (unless `PatternType.THREETEN` was specified where the JSR-310-team deviates from CLDR regarding this detail).

In short: CLDR is not simply ISO so ISO-features don't apply for general date patterns.

issues.title: Document pattern order in case of or-logic applied
issues.body:
This is a minor documentation issue. Two things should be noted for or-logic (in `ChronoFormatter.Builder` and `MultiFormatParser`) :

a) If two patterns or formatters are combined then the order must be from the most complete pattern/formatter to the least complete one. Example: Use "MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm|MM/dd/yyyy" and not "MM/dd/yyyy|MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm". This is especially important if the formatter in question use default values because the single components will be processed before evaluating any default values (which is a late step in parsing).

b) If two patterns/formatters have the same degree of completeness then that component should be noted first which is more likely to be expected in input.

issues.title: PUSH-FORWARD-strategy is not suitable for intervals
issues.body:
When converting timestamp intervals to moment intervals, Time4J does implicitly use the default transition strategy based on PUSH_FORWARD. However, this can cause start-after-end-conditions in some rare cases preventing the creation of new moment interval.

Solution:

The transition strategy should always be based on GapResolver.NEXT_VALID_TIME. Therefore two methods in `DateInterval` and `TimestampInterval` accepting a parameter of type `Timezone` will be marked as deprecated. In addition, a new method `public MomentInterval inTimezone(TZID)` will be added to `DateInterval`.

Under some exotic circumstances, the actuallly implemented prescan phase of parsing ISO-interval strings is not always correct. Examples:

issues.title: Clarify format behaviour if zoneless types are combined with zone names
issues.body:
Code like 

``` Java
    ChronoFormatter<PlainTimestamp> f =
        ChronoFormatter.ofTimestampPattern("yyyy-MM-dd z", PatternType.CLDR, Locale.ENGLISH)
        .withTimezone(EUROPE.BERLIN);
    System.out.println(f.format(PlainDate.of(2016, 4, 20).atStartOfDay()));
```

produces this error message:

> java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot extract timezone id from: 2016-04-20T00

Unfortunately the error message is not quite clear, and the documentation of method `ChronoFormatter.Builder.addShortTimezoneName()` etc. does not mention this exception. So the fix will consist of better error message and better documentation. Specifically, **timezone names can only be combined with global instant-like types** (like `Moment` or `ZonalDateTime`).

For comparison, Java-8 (JSR-310) has chosen the alternative road to support a so called "generic non-location format" in such cases, see also the [SO-post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36722873/datetimeformatter-not-compatible-with-simpledateformat). The best existing API for accessing or defining data for generic formats so far is given by `DateFormatSymbols.getZoneStrings()` and the SPI-interface `java/util/spi/TimeZoneNameProvider` . However, Time4J will actually not go this road because 
- for true conformance to [LDML](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr35/tr35-dates.html#Using_Time_Zone_Names), we have to recognize that the pattern symbol "z" only stands for the specific non-location format, but not for the generic non-location format,
- it is harmful for the performance of parsing timezone names (already expensive now) because additional data would have to be taken into account,
- there is hardly a sensible use-case for generic names because most people just use either standard (winter) or summer time format, 
- Time4J might support generic-non-location formats in the future via the pattern symbol "v" requiring extra builder-methods,
- we have also to consider the actual fact that Android does not have any data for generic format..

**Conclusion:** The error message should contain a note about the specific non-location format (what "z" stands for) which cannot be achieved with zoneless types in a reliable way.

issues.title: Refine localized calendar history in Europe
issues.body:
**First part: Various important regions in Europe are not yet handled.**

`ChronoHistory.of(Locale)` needs an update of implementation (at least major regions like DE, FR, IT are missing) AND documentation (stressing the point that this method is only an approximation based on partially unreliable sources).

**Second part: Investigate history of New Year in Russia.**

Byzantine calendar in Russia used begin of September until 1700. However, it seems that this begin might be related to the previous calendar year not current calendar year, see also:

http://www.prlib.ru/en-us/history/Pages/Item.aspx?itemid=364 (last time of celebration 1698, not 1699 - at least in the view of Christian era)

Maybe also this literature helps to decide: "S. I. Seleschnikow: Wieviel Monde hat ein Jahr?" (German)

issues.title: v3.3/4.2: Don't cache system timezone in "SystemClock.inLocalView()"
issues.body:
Caching the system timezone at initialization time is not okay because the user might have changed the sys-tz in the meantime. The actual behaviour does not fit at all to the expectations of users so this behaviour should be classified and fixed as a bug. 

The original idea behind caching was to design Time4J such that users will and should not change the sys-tz. While changing the sys-tz is surely not a good idea on standard client or server machines Time4J cannot really stop users here by design. And mobile platforms have different requirements where it can be quite common to change the sys-tz (for example on travels across several timezones). Users should also keep in mind that changing the sys-tz on **non-mobile** platforms still requires setting the system property "net.time4j.allow.system.tz.override". That feature remains valid.

Note that the class `AbstractClock` in the misc-module is affected, too.

issues.title: Improve I18n-support for number symbols and RTL-languages
issues.body:
The JDK-data based on the class `DecimalFormatSymbols` are notoriously unreliable as some tests with persian language revealed. Especially the minus sign and the right-to-left-style cause problems here. The situation on Android devices is probably even worse.
- The minus sign should be specified as String, not as char like in JDK-data. This enables a sequence of RLM-or LRM-marker followed by the localized minus char in persian (farsi). This technic helps to control the orientation of the minus-sign (right or left to the number).
- In general, users should set the RTL-context, not Time4J (so Time4J should not try to correct it by introducing an RLM-marker before every number in duration formatting as it does it now in v2.0). A recommended approach for users in context of HTML or XML will be for example setting the universal CSS-attribute dir="rtl".

A solution requires a new SPI-interface `NumberSymbolProvider` and some small enhancements and corrections to the class `PrettyTime`.

issues.title: Specify behaviour more clearly using extreme values
issues.body:
This is especially about the class `Moment` and the methods `plus()` and `minus()` using SI-units. The spec is until now silent what will happen if someone tries to add one SI-second to the maximum value on the time axis of `Moment`. The current behaviour is throwing an `IllegalArgumentException`. 

However, the other `plus()`\- and `minus()`-methods defined in super class `TimePoint` are specified to throw an `ArithmeticException`. Really they also throw an `IllegalArgumentException` if applied on extreme values. Note that this bug (as difference between spec and behaviour) is not so important because a) the user gets an exception anyway and b) only occurs when using exotic extreme values. Nevertheless it is mentioned for completeness. Note also that the class `PlainTime` does not throw an exception because of its rolling nature (rolling at midnight).

**Solution:**

All `plus()`\- and `minus()`-methods should consistently throw an `ArithmeticException` in such overflow cases.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
fix for zone transition problem

see issue #122

issues.title: Default transition strategy not correct for invalid local times
issues.body:
**Problem:** While the default transition strategy itself yields the correct offset (choosing the later offset after a gap as specified) the processing of the result must also take into account that in case of a gap the local time has to be shifted forward the same manner. Otherwise a transformation of midnight in Brazil on 2014-10-19 (summer time change) to a moment and then back will yield a winter timestamp one hour before. This is unfortunate.

**Solution:** Without having access to a timezone transition history the code must construct a new `GregorianCalendar`-instance and simulates the transition there and then transfer the result to determine the right moment. This is not so good for the performance, but shows the importance of later milestone M5 (where an access to transition history is finally possible).

issues.title: Final fixing of class Duration
issues.body:
a) The method design for  class `Duration` was originally orientated partially on the Joda-class `Period` which has `plus()`\- and `minus()`-methods. But the sign handling is fundamentally different, so especially the `minus()`-methods are inherently unsafe (throwing an exception in many cases not expected by users) and should be removed.This is breaking source and binary compatibility but justified because of the still low distribution of Time4J and the high risk of these methods.

b) The sign check for the methods `plus()` and `with()` can be simplified which is easier to understand: These methods should fail if the signs of duration-instance and arguments are different and else succeed. Simple for users and simple for implementation. This is only a very minor behavioural incompatibility which can be tolerated regarding the standard use cases.

c) The method `union` should change the return type to `List<Duration<?>>` in order to enable a flexible handling of a result with mixed signs. In this case the user can decide if he/she wants to throw an exception or just use the result as sequence of arithmetic steps. This feature is a good contrasting supplement to the behaviour and signature of  `plus(TimeSpan)`-method although this is also a binary incompatible break (tolerable regarding the current low distribution of Time4J).

d) For naming consistency, the method `parse(String)` should be renamed to `parsePeriod(String)` to help users to understand that this is really parsing canonical P-strings which must not be mixed up with the method `parse(CharSequence)` of class `Duration.Formatter`. The old method in class `Duration` can then be deprecated.

The priority of these changes is high because later it is really too late for such incompatible breaks.

issues.title: 24:00-time-arithmetic in PlainTimestamp broken
issues.body:
I have to apologize for this serious bug:

`System.out.println(PlainTimestamp.of(2014, 1, 31, 23, 59).plus(1, ClockUnit.MINUTES));`
// 2014-02-02T00 (one day too much)

This problem arises if clock units are added such to a timestamp that the result is exactly on another day without time remainder.

The bug is caused by special and wrong treatment for the time 24:00 when it comes to transfer the day-overflow. Unfortunately this error propagates to other places like in `Moment`, too. The whole thing required a new release schedule hence the splitting of milestone M3 in two, namely M3a and M3b in order to release the bugfix as soon as possible.

Unfortunately during a former refactoring following error was built-in:
